image.altText: A collection of credit cards.

props.synopsis: Australians lost an estimated $2.2 billion to card fraud last year, according to new data released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

title.children: Almost 2 million people were victims of card fraud in 2023 as hardest hit group identified

props.synopsis: Police have clashed with Tibetan and Uyghur activists outside the Chinese embassy where the group was protesting against the visit of Foreign Minister Wang Yi.

title.children: Tibetan activists protest outside Chinese embassy against Foreign Minister Wang Yi's visit

image.altText: A mid shot of WA Ombudsman Chris Field and his lawyer Christian Porter next to a car outside the CCC.

props.synopsis: WA's Ombudsman tells the Corruption and Crime Commission he has voluntarily stood down as president of the international ombudsman body while the CCC probe into his lavish international travel is ongoing.

title.children: Ombudsman subject to corruption probe over lavish travel quits plum international governance gig

image.altText: Burnt bushland near a rural property near Gidgegannup

props.synopsis: A bushfire that threatened lives and homes in Perth's hills has been downgraded to a 'watch and act', after burning for 24 hours at emergency level.

title.children: Homes saved from 'suspicious' Perth hills bushfire as fire alert level downgraded

image.altText: Glen Mervyn dam low water levels

props.synopsis: Water in Glen Mervyn Dam, 200km south of Perth, has dropped by 80 per cent in a year, prompting calls for growers to future-proof their orchards.

title.children: Fruit growers facing difficult future as key WA dam dries up

image.altText: Bearded man wearing black hat and glasses, standing behind money till in food store

props.synopsis: Tony Moore was $12,500 out of pocket after thieves stole his phone, but the money has been refunded by his bank.

title.children: Broome man returns crowdfunded cash after Westpac agrees to refund stolen money

image.altText: A close up of Kate Middleton smiling while wearing dangly earings.

props.synopsis: Britain's health minister says she's asked police to investigate claims staff at the hospital where Kate, Princess of Wales, had surgery in January, attempted to access her private medical records.

title.children: Claims hospital staff tried to access Kate Middleton's private health records referred to police

image.altText: A smiling blond woman

props.synopsis: Police concluded their search of bushland south of Ballarat on Wednesday afternoon after being unable to locate any trace of the missing woman.

title.children: Police unable to find Samantha Murphy after intelligence prompted new search south of Ballarat

image.altText: Angus Taylor, Jim Chalmers 20221026_192814850_iOS

props.synopsis: Shadow Treasurer Angus Taylor has accused Jim Chalmers of seeking to politicise the Reserve Bank by "stacking the board with his mates".

title.children: Coalition accuses treasurer of trying to put 'mates' on RBA board

image.altText: hands holding money from a wallet.

props.synopsis: They're calling it Penniless March, a challenge by a WA group to not only save cash in a cost-of-living crisis but consider more closely what a financial therapist calls a "total culture of spending".

title.children: No coffees out, no beers at the pub — could you go a month without non-essentials?

image.altText: A shipping tanker sits upside down in rough seas with only its red underside visible

props.synopsis: The tanker sent a distress call to the local coastguard before going under, with local authorities continuing to search for some missing crew members.

title.children: Eight people killed after South Korean chemical tanker carrying acrylic acid capsizes off Japan

image.altText: People taking photos of Hong Kong at sunset

props.synopsis: A controversial law has finally passed in Hong Kong. The government says it will keep the city safe, but critics call it the final nail in the coffin. Here's what you should know

title.children: Once a glittering financial hub, Hong Kong is facing a mass exodus. Critics say Article 23 will hasten the city's decline

image.altText: A man outside a car

props.synopsis: New data reveals the worst states and territories in Australia for car thefts, home invasions and other crimes during the last financial year.

title.children: With 55,000 cars stolen across Australia last financial year, ABS figures reveal household crimes are rising in Qld and NT

image.altText: A photo of a retail store in a shopping centre selling vacuum cleaners.

props.synopsis: Vacuum cleaner retail chain Godfreys will close by the end of May, after administrators were unable to find a suitable buyer to purchase the business, which had been struggling in the "challenging economic operating environment".

title.children: Godfreys to close for good after the vacuum cleaner retailer fails to find new buyer

image.altText: Population overload

props.synopsis: It is the 1 per cent, the handful of millionaires and billionaires who own more, consume more, control more, and destroy more than all the rest of us put together.

title.children: Population crisis: blame the 1 per cent

image.altText: A young woman with red hair smiles as she looks into the distance.

props.synopsis: With elections looming across the nation, the focus on housing in Tasmania's poll suggests governments are ready to take more radical steps to deal with our housing crisis.

title.children: 'No deposit' home loans, the end of Airbnb and immense rental protections all on the table in an election that could set the scene for other states

image.altText: Tom Price residents recount experiences with the mining town's aging hospital

props.synopsis: Tom Price residents are frequently forced to travel hours away for health services not offered at a hospital that was promised upgrades in 2021, and considered a slap in the face given the region's $35 billion a year contribution in mining.

title.children: Remote WA mining town begging state government to come good on promise to upgrade 57yo hospital

image.altText: Australian women's cricketer, Ash Gardner, completes a lofted drive, while a Bangladesh wicketkeeper watches.

props.synopsis: The only place to watch Australia's first women's cricket tour of Bangladesh since 2014 will be on YouTube after TV networks fail to secure a broadcast deal.

title.children: Australia's women's cricket tour of Bangladesh left off TV

image.altText: Beyonce on a white horse, carrying an American flag and wearing red, blue and white, with a white cowboy hat on

props.synopsis: Recording artist Beyoncé addresses criticism she has experienced since releasing several country-inspired singles as she gears up to release a new album.

title.children: 'This ain't a Country album. This is a Beyoncé album': Singer opens up about not feeling welcomed

image.altText: Emma sits on a couch in her home

props.synopsis: It's Pay Day! Emma McCaskill answers all the money questions we don't like to talk about as we seek to demystify personal finance and normalise conversations about how we think about money, what we earn and how we spend it.

title.children: How chef Emma McCaskill organises her money — and why she has two secret bank accounts

image.altText: Colourful ribbons on a church ground fence

props.synopsis: The Diocese of Ballarat says it will remove ribbons tied outside St Patrick's Cathedral on Saturday morning, for the ageing wrought-iron fence to be painted.

title.children: Catholic Diocese says ribbons supporting child sex abuse survivors will be removed, but wants to talk about their future

image.altText: alexander csergo smiling at the camera, he is the australian man who was accused of foreign interference

props.synopsis: Alexander Csergo has spent nearly a year in custody after he was arrested in Bondi in April last year, accused of reckless foreign interference.

title.children: Crown drops allegation Sydney businessman prejudiced Australia's national security

image.altText: A composite of headshots of both men speaking at microphones.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump uses an appearance on British television to insult Australia's ambassador to the US, Kevin Rudd, suggesting he might not remain in the role if the former president is re-elected.

title.children: Donald Trump insults ambassador Kevin Rudd, says 'he won't be there long' if he's 'hostile'

image.altText: Night time photo of Whyalla steelworks.

props.synopsis: The stakes are again high for the steel town of Whyalla as a billionaire owner who has broken past promises looks to a green future.

title.children: Whyalla's billionaire owner Sanjeev Gupta is under pressure on a global scale and it's making steelworkers nervous

image.altText: A very frail little baby girl

props.synopsis: Watin was a happy and healthy two-year-old before the Israel-Gaza war. Now her mother fears she will starve to death before Gaza receives enough humanitarian aid.

title.children: 'Leaving me little by little': Khouloud is watching her daughter starve to death and can't stop it

image.altText: A firefighter looking through the front window of a truck at a house engulfed by flames.

props.synopsis: Fire and Rescue New South Wales has recorded more than 60 lithium-ion battery fires in the state so far in 2024.

title.children: Beachside homes evacuated as another suspected lithium-ion battery fire destroys house

image.altText: Palestinians crowd together as they wait for food distribution in Rafah, southern Gaza Strip.

props.synopsis: Life in Rafah is catastrophic as over a million Palestinian refugees deal with hunger and a looming land invasion.

title.children: Gaza resident describes life in Rafah as Israel plans assault on the 'safe zone'

image.altText: An illustration of a woman on a sofa leans into a robot

props.synopsis: For centuries, human societies have been supercharged by the arrival of disruptive technology so remarkable they changed the trajectory of human history. The next one has already arrived.

title.children: 'The greatest heist of all time': What life will be like when the singularity takes hold

image.altText: A snake lies coiled on sand in the sun.

props.synopsis: The 47-year-old man suffered several snake bites before returning home to tell his wife, who applied first aid.

title.children: Wife desperately tried to save man fatally bitten by snake at Queensland childcare centre

image.altText: RBA governor Michele Bullock holds her hand up while speaking at a press conference.

props.synopsis: The RBA appears to have learnt from past mistakes by opening up its interest rate options while it waits to see if its November rate rise tipped Australia's economy into a worrying downward spiral.

title.children: The Reserve Bank has opened up its options because it's not sure just how bad Australia's economy is going to get

image.altText: A crowd of people line up with luggage

props.synopsis: The Coalition has argued for domestic travellers to be compensated when airlines delay or cancel flights, or when their luggage is lost or damaged in transit, as their 'Pay on Delay' bill is debated in the Senate.

title.children: Travellers should be paid for cancelled or delayed flights and lost luggage, Coalition argues

image.altText: Four people look at the camera, two have been blurred, and the unblurred people are smiling.

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory's shadow family violence minister Steve Edgington has suspended a staffer in his electorate office after revelations he had been jailed for domestic violence offences.

title.children: NT politician suspends staffer jailed for DV offences

image.altText: A woman in a black blazer smiles at the camera in front of a fake 'Tasmanien government' background

props.synopsis: Staff at a media company that produces satirical political videos are warned they could face jail time and a fine over a video that shows Tasmanian Premier Jeremy Rockliff's face, as it could be seen as "advertisement".

title.children: 'Honest Government Ad' posted by satirical media company censored following complaint to Tasmanian Electoral Commission

image.altText: A blonde woman sits on a ride with a little redheaded boy and a blonde boy

props.synopsis: As sons of the sovereign, Harry and William can't totally escape the media, but the way they deal with this interest in their lives couldn't be more different.

title.children: How Harry and William's shared trauma is driving their very different approaches to a common enemy
